IOC åˆ°åº•æ˜¯ä»€ä¹ˆ

InÂ software engineering,Â inversion of controlÂ (IoC) is a programming principle. IoC inverts theÂ flow of controlÂ as compared to traditional control flow. In IoC, custom-written portions of aÂ computer programÂ receive the flow of control from a genericÂ framework. AÂ software architectureÂ with this design inverts control as compared to traditionalÂ procedural programming: in traditional programming, the custom code that expresses the purpose of the programÂ callsÂ into reusable libraries to take care of generic tasks, but with inversion of control, it is the framework that calls into the custom, or task-specific, code.
